article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on micro-generation and related energy technologies and practices for low carbon buildings

abstract.p: Proposed future UK energy supply infrastructures harbour ambitions for achieving a sustainable and reliable energy network, which can potentially be realised through a decentralised and flexible approach to electricity generation. Such an energy system will be expected to deliver these objectives through the widespread use of distributed energy resources, thereby contributing to the international aim of a low carbon future. Existing research in the area of distributed energy resource integration has developed the energy hub methodology [Geidl M, Koeppel G, Favre-Perrod P, et al. The energy hub – a powerful concept for future energy systems. In: Proceedings of the third annual Carnegie Mellon conference on the electricity industry, Tepper School of Business, Carnegie Mellon University, 13–14 March 2007, pp.1–10.] to formally model flows within an energy network, abstracting generation from multiple energy carriers (e.g. electricity, wind and natural gas) and allowing a modular energy network construction that facilitates optimal placement of distributed energy resources within each hub. This article will present the energy hub approach to modelling a decentralised energy network, illustrated with two case studies from the East and West coasts of Scotland. The resulting analysis will show the impact of two scenarios with different energy mixes available whilst reflecting the subtle differences in demands across areas with different weather profiles. This is a fundamental progression of existing distributed energy resource research to date in that individual characteristics and costs of a mixture of technologies are modelled. Such analysis will be pivotal in planning future networks to ensure that they function optimally and also in directing policy to encourage consumers to adopt a different approach to energy generation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In-line with the EU Renewable Energy Directive, the UK must endeavour to generate 20% of its total energy from renewable sources by 2020. More ambitiously, within the same timeframe, the Scottish Government aim to have 100% of electricity demand and 11% of heat demand delivered by renewable sources.1 Such targets may be met with a highly decentralised network,2 incorporating large levels of distributed generation. Such a topology would have to enable the system to function as a sustainable and reliable energy network. Through the widespread use of distributed energy resources (DERs), the full potential of these devices may be exploited by the power system in that the benefits they provide in terms of supporting the current electricity and gas networks during peak load would assist in delivering the stable energy network that is required, whilst meeting EU targets.

This article presents a model of sectors of Scotland’s energy network that challenges the current ‘fit-and-forget’ approach that currently exists with the integration of DERs, as the current top–down topology does not facilitate and maximise the benefits of, for example, bidirectional power flows that DERs create. This article aims to exploit the benefits of DERs within an integrated modelling framework – by utilising them to increase reliability (lowering dependence on a single energy source to meet demands) and take renewable availability (i.e. intermittency) into account.

In 2010, the domestic sector accounted for over 30% of final energy consumption in the UK.3 It becomes apparent, therefore, that in order to meet ambitious government targets, the domestic sector must engage significantly with a renewable approach to generating electricity.

There has already been a significant body of academic research effort into different aspects of distributed generation and decentralisation of the electricity network.4,5 Current research anticipates that through the deployment of behaviour changes in energy use (e.g. driven by smart meters) and through the widespread deployment of small-scale distributed generation, the nature of the electrical system will change.6

However, by analysing micro-technologies in this way, any model will not reflect each individual characteristic, nor can the different costs associated with each technology be accounted for at a more specific level. As one of the main aims would be to optimise the system in terms of cost minimisation (an important factor for both consumers and generators), whilst always ensuring the system remains reliable and secure, it is imperative that a more involved analysis of micro-generation is carried out.

One approach to the management of ever increasing penetration levels of small-scale DERs will be to consider the power (and energy) system(s) in smaller parts. Advantages of dividing the distribution network into smaller sections include increased levels of local generation, with less reliance on the national grid, reduced losses and easier grid management. This article adopts an approach that segregates the energy system into a number of constituent elements of smaller ‘local’ decentralised energy networks, where each portion has its own load, generation and network considerations. The model presented will find the least cost optimal mix of energy carriers for each localised energy network, ensuring the energy needs of the consumers are met. The analysis is carried out for a winter’s and a summer’s day, in two contrasting scenarios.

The rest of the article is structured as follows; the following section presents the energy hubs and their operation in full. Then, the details of the existing methods for modelling energy systems and a case for energy hubs being the most suitable for this research is given. Subsequently, ‘Case studies – Western and Eastern Scotland’ section stipulates the problem this article tackles and how the associated model functions. Next, ‘Problem formulation’ section describes the two case studies analysed before ‘Results and discussion’ and ‘Conclusions and further work’ sections discuss the results generated from the model and outline future progressions.

sec.title: Energy hubs
sec.p: In this study, the decentralised energy system will be modelled through the use of energy hubs. Energy hubs act as a ‘black box’, grouping together components within a small section of the network. Each of these sections will contain a certain mix of micro-generation technologies (micro-combined heat and power (CHP), solar photovoltaic (PV) panels and wind turbines). As Scotland accounts for over 25% of Europe’s wind resource, wind turbines in particular should be used extensively in order for the country to meet government renewable energy targets.7,8 The inputs to an energy hub consist of different energy carriers (electricity, natural gas, wind, etc.). The hub model then takes these inputs and performs a series of conversions by utilising the components inside, to meet certain levels of output. Thus, energy hubs present two problems that need to be solved; optimising flow between hubs and optimising the configuration within the hub itself.9

The inputs and outputs of a single hub are grouped together to become vectors P and L, respectively. A coupling matrix C is applied to the hub inputs P to give the desired outputs L. The coupling matrix consists of coupling factors, determined by converter efficiencies and hub topologies. A single energy carrier within the hub is, therefore, expressed as (1)L=CP

‘Case studies – Western and Eastern Scotland’ section will explain further how energy hubs are utilised to represent different areas of Scotland for the purposes of finding the least cost optimal energy mix in each of the locations.

It is possible to include storage in the energy hub framework, using another set of matrices configured to the efficiencies of the respective technologies. Whilst important for future analyses, the potential to store excess electricity has not been incorporated within the scope of this article; this article aims to analyse generation capabilities and least cost optimal mixes exclusively.

sec.title: Energy systems modelling
sec.p: To date, micro-generation has largely been treated as an aggregated DER or investigations examine sole technology types. In Thomson and Infield,10 the grid impacts of PV panel penetration are analysed and solutions presented. Also, Calderaro et al.11 assess the control and management of micro-wind turbines integrated into a low-voltage network. Kuzle et al.12 differentiate between two micro-technologies (solar PV panels and wind turbines) but deals only with one individual sector (or micro-grid) of the energy network. However, by analysing micro-technologies in this way, these works fail to reflect individual efficiencies and intermittencies and fail to account for different costs associated with each technology at a more specific level. As one of the main aims would be to optimise the system in terms of cost minimisation (an important factor for both consumers and generators), whilst always ensuring the system remains reliable and secure, it is imperative that a more involved analysis into the impacts of micro-generation is carried out.
In terms of the approaches that have been designed for the analysis of a multi-energy carrier system, various have been utilised in the literature.

The approach used for the research within this article, energy hubs, has been outlined in the previous section. Previous literature on energy hubs includes Geidl et al.,9 which examined the energy hub as a means of considering the combination of electricity and other energy carriers in a power system. In Geidl and Andersson,13 renewable technologies are considered within the hub model but not as individual carriers in their own right (e.g. micro-wind, solar PV, etc.), instead they are treated as a collective source. The energy hub is also looked at in Hemmes14 expanding the methodology by focussing on byproducts and how the concept of trigeneration systems could be integrated into larger power systems. The work in Hemmes14 only went so far in that it analyses only one technology and also the approach is suited to large-scale chemical plant and not aimed at low-voltage micro-generation. This did lead, however, to the development of multi-source multi-product systems that this article will build upon; a multi-source multi-product system being one with multiple inputs/energy carriers and multiple outputs. This development is necessary for modelling distinct energy carriers as inputs – not just an electricity supply form the grid. This article aims to apply the energy hub to a new problem in that multiple hubs are modelled with a mixture of possible renewable energy sources contained in each.
Energy hubs can be used to model unit commitment, economic dispatch or optimal power flow problems between areas of the network, depending on how the concept is applied.15

In Pudjianto et al.,16 a review of the virtual power plant (VPP) concept is presented. Under this method, groups of DERs are aggregated to form a VPP. The VPPs are controllable and, in essence, allow DERs to be incorporated into analyses in much the same way as traditional, transmission-connected plant are. VPPs encapsulate all voltage levels of the energy network, i.e. low, medium and high and each individual VPP has its own controller to regulate behaviour. The local controllers are in turn subordinate to one central controller that take precedence over the rest as a means of monitoring the system as a whole to ensure reliability and stability desires are met. Problems tackled using the VPP methodology mainly use the approach as a mechanism for representing energy markets where there are high level of distributed generation. In Kuzle et al.,12 a singular VPP is modelled to investigate the impacts of poor long-term weather forecast on systems with high penetration of weather-dependant renewables but does not model a network of interconnected VPP and focuses on determining the resultant reliance on conventional power plant. In Dielmann and Van Der Velden,17 the VPP is used for the development of the central management system, and to test the impact of virtual systems on open energy markets. In Vale et al.,18 virtual power players are used, a concept which differs from VPPs in only a few cosmetic details. The players aggregate DERs in order that smaller section of a network may participate in energy markets. This study which does investigate a number of decentralised grids together, however, does not factor in weather factors and is heavily biased towards solar distributed generation. In addition, the levels of DER are fixed and analyses are not geared towards finding a least cost optimal energy mix.

The main difference between energy hubs and VPP approach is the capability of analysing whichever voltage level of the network the problem requires. As such, energy hubs can be more focussed on smaller areas of the network for more detailed analyses, without necessarily having to include high-voltage generation in order to model markets. Also, energy hubs have the capability within the intrinsic matrix framework to correctly model the conversion of multiple energy sources, taking into account the efficiencies of the technologies included within the hubs.

In order to accurately represent small-scale supply and demand within this article, an approach is required that will deal with micro-generation technologies as separate entities. Without distinguishing between the different energy carriers, location specific variables such as weather characteristics will be lost. Furthermore, the subtle differences in demands across areas with different weather profiles will not be reflected within the models. This is a fundamental issue with existing DER research to date. As such, energy hubs provide the most suitable format for modelling a low-voltage energy system, being able to incorporate specific efficiencies and costs associated with each technology included.

sec.title: Case studies – Western and Eastern Scotland
sec.p:
The first case study focuses on Western Scotland (Figure 2). This region stretches from Tiree in the North West to Dumfries in the far South and is modelled as a network of 14 hubs, representing local education authorities (LEAs). LEAs have been chosen as the hub boundaries for the purposes of this research as populations and, therefore, potential for micro-generation penetration are able to be modelled closely whilst keeping model complexity within acceptable boundaries. Also, future policy and feed-in-tariffs may be tailored to suit particular regions. Modelling at this LEA level across the country creates the opportunity for arriving at, and advising on, such policies. Figure 2.
Map of Western Scotland outlining each of the 14 hubs.

Energy can flow directly between neighbouring hubs (i.e. those LEAs that share a border). As can be observed from Figure 2, LEAs in this region share many borders with each other. Indeed, the City of Glasgow (circled in Figure 2) has six possible neighbouring cells from which to receive energy, should it be necessary. In theory, this connectivity should allow for simple energy flows within the hub network.

Western Scotland covers a diverse landscape including the Western half of the Southern Uplands and the Central Lowlands. As a whole, this region accounts for just over 47% of the total population of Scotland. There are many large towns in the region but only one city, Glasgow. The different sizes and load profiles for each LEA are reflected within the model.

The average mean temperature in the West of Scotland is between 9.4 °C and 9.7 °C. Overall, temperatures are generally milder than those found in the East due to the impact of the warm Gulf Stream on the coast and the urban heat island effect in more central areas around Glasgow. These mean temperatures drop slightly in the northern and southern extremes of the region as they have higher altitudes.

Considering micro-generation potential, the number of hours of sunshine is dependent upon altitude, latitude, topography and distance from the coast. The low-lying islands, Kintyre and the Solway coast are amongst the West of Scotland’s sunniest areas with 1450 h of sunshine on average. This decreases to less than 1100 h for the West Highlands.

Due to its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, Western Scotland is very exposed to wind, presenting great potential for micro-wind turbines. Winds are at their highest during the winter months and at their lowest form June to August. This negates some of issues created by the dullness and lack of sunshine (and therefore potential solar PV generation) in the winter.

The second case study for comparison is the region of Eastern Scotland (Figure 3). Similarly to Western Scotland, there is a network of 14 hubs and again they are representative of LEAs. As in the West, energy can flow between LEAs that share a border. In this structural sense, however, Eastern Scotland is significantly different from the West in that the Firth of Forth separates many LEAs and, therefore, limits the number of LEAs that can share a border and, as such limits the number of directly connected hubs. Energy can still flow but, in general, it will have to pass through more hubs to travel from source hub to sink hub. Figure 3.
Map of Eastern Scotland outlining each of the 14 hubs.

Although the highest point in this region is higher than that in the West because of the inclusion of some of the Grampian region, the East is generally on lower ground than the West. The population in the region as a whole is comparable to the West at just over 47% of the Scottish population; however, there are differences in the spread of the population and layout of the region. Eastern Scotland has three cities (Edinburgh, Dundee and Aberdeen, as circled in Figure 3) and on average the authorities out with them are larger than those in the West. This immediately presents a different network layout to the West, with the nature of the somewhat linear flows creating more potential intermediate hubs.

As stated previously, temperatures in the East are lower but they also have a greater spread, ranging from less than 6 °C in the Grampians to approximately 9 °C around the Firth of Forth. Indeed, in the coldest month of January, the average temperature falls below −2 °C in the higher ground. Eastern Scotland includes more sunny areas than Western Scotland. Fife averages 1500 h of sunshine and East Lothian over 1400 h. It does include areas across the Grampians with less than 1100 h of sunshine though, which is comparable with the West.

The near proximity of Eastern Scotland to the track of Atlantic depressions causes frequent and strong winds, particularly in the months from December to January, resulting in some of the highest micro-wind potential in the UK.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: Each of the hubs considered in this study consists of an electricity transformer and technologies for micro-generation, namely micro-CHP, PV solar panels and a micro-wind turbine. Previously, it was stated that energy hubs present two distinct optimisation problems – optimal power flow between hubs and optimal layout of technologies within a hub. The particular application in this article involves finding the optimal use of existing technologies to find the minimum cost for generating the demand level present within a hub. For each case study outlined in section ‘Case studies – Western and Eastern Scotland’, this can be represented mathematically for hub j (contained within set of hubs H) as minfj(x)=∑i=1nCtijxij (4)xi∈ℜ∀j∈HH={h1,h2,…,h14} such that (5)Cj[x1jx2jx3jx4j]-Dj=0 where xij is the ith energy carrier in hub j, Ctij the cost of generation of the ith energy carrier in hub j, Cpj the coupling matrix in hub j and Dj the demand in hub j.

Additionally, energy can flow between the hubs in order to meet demand across the network. Hubs where energy is exported from are known as source hubs, and the destination hub is known as a sink hub. Energy may also flow between intermediate hubs so that flows are not restricted to neighbouring hubs. Energy flowing from hub j1 to j2, f1,2 is represented by a positive flow from j1 to j2 and an equal and negative flow from j2 to j1. The model detailed in this article does not take into account any storage facilities.

The model given by equations (4) and (5) is used to minimise the cost of generation based on specific technologies and costs within a hub. In each hub, if there is not enough potential supply to meet demand, the model attempts to transport energy from another hub in the network. The cost for generation is then increased to take into account the cost of transportation. When all renewable energy is exhausted, then grid supplies are used to ensure demand is met. Figure 4 shows the model’s operation graphically. Figure 4.
Flow chart representative of hub model operation.

The layout of each case study and the 14 hubs contained within is shown in Figure 5(a) and (b). These figures help to illustrate how different the layouts of the case studies are. There are a high number of connections in the West of Scotland, and in general hubs have links to a number of other hubs. There are no hubs with only one connection, i.e. no isolated hubs. In the East of Scotland where the layout is different, hubs 3 and 6 represent the two cities of Aberdeen and Dundee and as can be observed from the figure, these hubs are isolated. This is in complete contrast to the West’s City of Glasgow (hub 7) which is connected to six other hubs. Figure 5.
Schematic of hub layout and flow networks within Western and Eastern case studies (numbered in relation to Table 1).

The technologies were modelled based on typical efficiencies for 4 kw solar PV, 1.5 kW micro-wind turbines and 2 kW micro-CHP with respective feed-in tariffs of 43.3, 36.2 and 10.5 p/kWh generated.21 The weather data are based on average temperatures and so it is assumed that the technologies are either working at maximum or are not operational. To account for areas with greater potential for either solar or wind, the maximum levels were adjusted to reflect the fact more technologies could be installed.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Using the two case studies described above, simulations were carried out for two exemplar days in summer, and two in winter, analysing the extremes of electricity and heat demand. UK GDS data were used for this analysis and adjusted as necessary to reflect the different populations across each hub proportionately.22 Heating demand data were gathered from BERR.23

The Department for the Environment and Climate Change (DECC) has developed a series of pathways.24 These pathways have been collated in the form of a tool that enables the creation of possible courses, or pathways, for the UK energy network to take in the future. The output from the tool is a visualisation of predicted demand and supply over the time frame of 2010–2050.

The first scenario used for this research was developed based on Level 1 of the DECC pathways. It represents a little effort being made across all sectors by the incumbent actors in order to work towards a low carbon future. In essence, it signifies a move towards electric heating and electricity is favoured over gas for domestic cooking. Also, micro-wind turbines and solar PV panels are installed in 40% of homes and micro-CHP turbines in 20%. The combination of all these elements provides the context for the Scottish Case studies. The second scenario, based on Level 3 of the DECC pathways sees a fall in demand of 35% and the penetration levels of micro-generation were doubled. The scenarios have been applied across each hub network and are based on the year 2050.

The relative cost of generation across 2 days across both scenarios is shown in Figure 6(a) and (b). Figure 6.

From the above figures, it is evident that overall for scenario 1, the cost of generation for Eastern Scotland as a whole is far greater. In fact results show that in the winter, the cost is 57% more for the East of Scotland in this Scenario. This is explained by the average lower temperatures experienced in this part of the country and also that due to the nature of the hub (sub regions) layout, flows of electricity are more likely to pass through a greater number of intermediate hubs than in the West. Although both cost curves have a similar shape, the noticeable peak at 1900 h has a greater percentage rise in the East than in the West. This coincides with the peak evening demand and suggests that as it is colder in the East, consumers have more devices switched on and a greater demand for heating. In the West, the regions of North and South Lanarkshire, and the City of Glasgow had insufficient demand within their own region around this time. In the East, Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, Fife and Perth and Kinross all experienced the same situation. At this time, micro-generation potential was exhausted in the East and so greater pressure was put on the grid, hence the considerable rise in cost at this time. The rise in cost was not as significant in the West again because of the opportunities for flows between interconnected hubs.

Again, in the summer, the costs are higher in the East. In the summer, however, the sharp peaks in demand are not experienced, in particular in the evening where heating and lighting demands place a large amount of pressure on the distribution system. This explains the more linear cost curves during this day, with the slight increase during the night explained by the need for some increase in heating demand in certain areas of the country; whilst it is summer, this does not imply the temperatures are necessarily high.

Figure 6(b) shows the relative costs of scenario 2, and the implications of this change are evident in both the winter and summer days. In the winter, energy costs are now higher in Western Scotland. The margin between the two is not as great as in scenario 1 but the reversal is significant. In the East, with far greater levels of micro-generation, transport costs associated with energy flows are less than before as more electricity is generated locally, with lesser dependence from the greater population densities of Edinburgh, etc., on both the electricity grid and resources from other hubs within the network.

This trend is mirrored in the summer but to a lesser extent. Now there is very little difference in the costs for Western and Eastern Scotland. Most significantly, both costs are negative. This indicates consumer profiting from their generation. Whilst this is possible for the few today, it would not be realistic for this to be the case for the majority in 2050. This highlights that whilst FiTs are a great incentive for installing micro-technologies presently, they are unsustainable at their current levels. This scenario, however, does represent a massive shift in attitude from consumers, where they become far more energy aware. By 2050, FiTs would perhaps not be necessary if this was to be the case.

Figure 7(a) and (b) above shows the least cost optimised energy mix across all hubs in Western and Eastern Scotland for the DECC study scenario 1. With each of the individual hubs connected to the gas grid it is clear that micro-CHP is the most favoured micro-technology. The results tend towards the maximum use of solar and wind potential when it is available. This is due to the fact that currently the consumers stand to make money on these generation types due to FiTs. Western Scotland has greater potential for micro-generation at this time of year, due to the availability of wind. This, coupled with its slightly higher temperatures in winter, and consequently lower demand profile, shows Western Scotland to have far more potential for using micro-turbines as a means of offsetting costs to domestic and commercial consumers. Eastern Scotland has experienced a drop in both reliance upon the electricity grid and the micro-CHP units, distributing this load amongst the micro-wind turbines and solar PV panels. This is symbolic of the massive change in costs for this region. Overall, Western Scotland is relatively unchanged in its overall energy mix. This shows that a hub network with many flows and connections will have a more stabilised energy profile than one with a more linear architecture. The majority of domestic electricity will continue to be drawn from the electricity grid. There are limits to how many installations domestic consumers can have and the attitude of consumers in terms of energy use and sources of energy will differ between individuals, maybe even between regions. Furthermore, the move towards electric heating will also place continuing demands on the electricity grid.

sec.title: Conclusions and further work
sec.p: This article has presented a method by which detailed modelling of local energy networks with multiple energy carriers can be utilised in novel analyses of generation and demand. Multiple micro-technologies have been modelled in isolation, as part of a discrete system, to solve an economic dispatch problem at a regional level using the energy hub concept. This approach has been demonstrated using an initial East/West comparison across regional Scotland, an inter-area regional formulation that has not been sufficiently studied in the previous literature. The initial results presented in this article under two DECC derived scenarios have, in one case, shown Western Scotland to have lower generation costs than Eastern Scotland, signifying the impact on overall cost of generation that a highly decentralised network with many connecting flows can have. As the number of installations increase, however, more energy can be produced locally and it has been shown that the greater impact in cost reduction will be experienced in more linear hub topologies. Continuing this research will include modelling hubs with more potential generation technologies, and storage technologies, which will allow the most successful micro-generators, in terms of cost reduction and other features such as carbon emissions, to be identified for small regions of the country. The localisation of generation through community adoption and increasing degrees of penetration of distributed generation, potentially presents a problem for DNOs if left unmanaged and understanding the nature of the interactions and bulk flows of energy can inform planners, DNOs, local and central government incentives as they head towards a low carbon future. As such, ongoing research also includes formulating a plan on how these mixes may be achieved, and what factors may prove to be obstacles, and indeed the real costs associated with any necessary operational changes.
